pred: The first thing to look for in any chest radiograph is a pneumothorax.  There are two in this one.  Notice how the right pleural edge is visible, and the pleural space is visible above it. The key to option A is the presence of a visceral pleural line.   The key to option B is the absence of a visceral pleural line.

If you look at the top of the image, you will see the white arrows and the visceral pleural line both "disappear" at some point. question:
Does this chest X-ray show edema? Options:
A) Yes
B) No
pred: The CXR shows diffuse pulmonary edema.  There are two subtypes of pulmonary edema, cardiogenic and non-cardiogenic.  Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema is usually seen in the setting of fulminant hepatic failure, acute renal failure, and sepsis.  It is an important cause of acute respiratory distress, because these patients often do not have cardiogenic edema.  Cardiogenic pulmonary edema is caused by heart failure (most common cause), left to right shunts, and overcirculation.  It is important to remember that non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema can be seen in the setting of fulminant hepatic failure, acute renal failure, and sepsis.  The cause of the pulmonary edema is not always clear.  In this case, it is likely cardiogenic, due to the patient’s recent 30-hour car ride.  The patient’s heart rate is also indicative of cardiogenic edema; she has a rate of 142 bpm.  This is within the 120-150 range of a resting heart rate.  The brain’s compensatory mechanism is to increase the heart rate to try and increase cardiac output.

question:
Does this chest X-ray show lung opacity? Options:
A) Yes
B) No
pred:
The key to answer this question is to recognize that there are 3 separate findings:

1) Recognize two separate, well-defined horizontal lines.

2) Recognize an ill-defined/diffuse opacity in the right lower lung zone.

3) Recognize the silhouette sign between the ill-defined opacity and the right heart border.

These findings are present in the image. The first two findings are very obvious. The third finding is less obvious but still very important in determining the diagnosis. The silhouette sign is only seen when the ill-defined opacity is outlined by the more dense and opaque hemidiaphragm. If the opacity is not obscuring the right heart border, it is less likely to be silhouetted out by the hemidiaphragm. This is why step 2 is so important. If the first two findings are recognized, then the third finding is much more likely to be seen. The answer is "No" if all three findings are recognized, or "Yes" if at least two of the findings are recognized.

A) Yes

pred:
The Radiographic features can be summarized as follows. Features include airspace opacification, filling of the alveoli with infectious material and pus, initially patchy and becomes confluent as the infection develops. Also, air bronchograms can be seen, which are air-filled bronchi running through pus-filled alveoli. Complications may include pleural collection and cavitation.
The answer is Yes.

pred:
The first image shows an enlarged cardiomediastinum.  There are 2 options for this finding.  Either the image shows an aortic aneurysm or pseudoaneurysm (Aortic Aneurysm Differential Diagnosis), or the image shows an aortic dissection (Aortic Dissection Differential Diagnosis).  

The next image shows the end of a worm (filar cyst), which is a common finding in patients with filariasis (a parasitic infection caused by ingestion of microfilariae, which mature into adult worms that produce microfilariae of their own).  The final image shows a Lambert sign (a V-shaped groove in the medial wall of the aorta adjacent to the insertion of the ligamentum arteriosum).
